title: Incorrect details on OAuth permissions screen allows DMs to be read without permission

profile.name: Twitter
profile.about: Twitter helps you create and share ideas and information instantly, without barriers.

vulnerability_information:
> NOTE! Thanks for submitting a report! Please replace *all* the [square] sections below with the pertinent details. Remember, the more detail you provide, the easier it is for us to triage and respond quickly, so be sure to take your time filling out the report!

**Summary:** 
The OAuth screen can be tricked into saying that an app cannot read Direct Messages. Despite that, DMs can be read.

**Description:** 
The official Twitter API keys have been leaked and are in use in several popular apps.
The iPhone keys and Google TV keys (as seen on https://gist.github.com/shobotch/5160017) present an OAuth screen which says the app "Will not be able to:   Access your direct messages."
This is false.  The apps *can* read DMs.

## Steps To Reproduce:

(Add details for how we can reproduce the issue)

  1. Ask the user to do the OAuth dance with a token generated from the official keys.
  1. User sees that the app cannot read DMs.
  1. User authorises.
  1. App now has unauthorised access to DMs.
  1. User is sad that their privacy has been violated.

## Impact: [add why this issue matters]
A user may not want a 3rd party app to have access to their DMs.

They rely on the OAuth screen to adequately inform them of the permissions they are granting.

Is this a GDPR violation? I'm not sure. You are telling users that the 3rd party app can't read their private information - but that is false. These API keys do allow access from *any* app which integrates them.

## Supporting Material/References:

  * Screenshot of the OAuth screen for Google TV
  * Screenshot of the OAuth screen for iPhone

## Impact

Unauthorised access to Direct Messages.
vulnerability_information_html:

Summary:

Description:
The official Twitter API keys have been leaked and are in use in several popular apps.

This is false. The apps can read DMs.

Steps To Reproduce:

  2. User sees that the app cannot read DMs.
  3. User authorises.
  4. App now has unauthorised access to DMs.
  5. User is sad that their privacy has been violated.

Impact: [add why this issue matters]

A user may not want a 3rd party app to have access to their DMs.

They rely on the OAuth screen to adequately inform them of the permissions they are granting.

Is this a GDPR violation? I'm not sure. You are telling users that the 3rd party app can't read their private information - but that is false. These API keys do allow access from any app which integrates them.

Supporting Material/References:

  • Screenshot of the OAuth screen for Google TV
  • Screenshot of the OAuth screen for iPhone

activities.message:
Hi edent,

Could you clarify as to which endpoints you're able to access DMs from?
activities.markdown_message:
Hi edent,

Could you clarify as to which endpoints you're able to access DMs from?

activities.message:
I'm able to access them from the Twitter API. So I guess you mean `api.twitter.com`?

Here is the proof-of-concept code. Python2. Click on the link - Twitter.com says there is no access to DMs. Authorise and type in the PIN. The code prints out your DMs.

```
#!/usr/bin/env python
import tweepy

# Official Keys
consumer_key    = 'IQKbtAYlXLripLGPWd0HUA'
consumer_secret = 'GgDYlkSvaPxGxC4X8liwpUoqKwwr3lCADbz8A7ADU'

# Set up the authorisation
auth = tweepy.OAuthHandler(consumer_key, consumer_secret)
auth.secure = True
auth_url = auth.get_authorization_url()
print 'Visit this URL and authorise the app to use your Twitter account: ' + auth_url
# The above URL says that there's no access to DMs

verifier = raw_input('Type in the generated PIN: ').strip()
auth.get_access_token(verifier)

# Full Auth
full_auth = tweepy.OAuthHandler(consumer_key, consumer_secret)
full_auth.set_access_token(auth.access_token, auth.access_token_secret)
api = tweepy.API(full_auth)

# Print all the user's Direct Messages
print api.direct_messages()
```
activities.markdown_message:
I'm able to access them from the Twitter API. So I guess you mean api.twitter.com?

Here is the proof-of-concept code. Python2. Click on the link - Twitter.com says there is no access to DMs. Authorise and type in the PIN. The code prints out your DMs.

#!/usr/bin/env python
import tweepy

# Official Keys
consumer_key    = 'IQKbtAYlXLripLGPWd0HUA'
consumer_secret = 'GgDYlkSvaPxGxC4X8liwpUoqKwwr3lCADbz8A7ADU'

# Set up the authorisation
auth = tweepy.OAuthHandler(consumer_key, consumer_secret)
auth.secure = True
auth_url = auth.get_authorization_url()
print 'Visit this URL and authorise the app to use your Twitter account: ' + auth_url
# The above URL says that there's no access to DMs

verifier = raw_input('Type in the generated PIN: ').strip()
auth.get_access_token(verifier)

# Full Auth
full_auth = tweepy.OAuthHandler(consumer_key, consumer_secret)
full_auth.set_access_token(auth.access_token, auth.access_token_secret)
api = tweepy.API(full_auth)

# Print all the user's Direct Messages
print api.direct_messages()

activities.message:
Thank you for your report. We believe it may be a valid security issue and will investigate it further. It could take some time to find and update the root cause for an issue, so we thank you for your patience.

Thank you for helping keep Twitter secure!
activities.markdown_message:
Thank you for your report. We believe it may be a valid security issue and will investigate it further. It could take some time to find and update the root cause for an issue, so we thank you for your patience.

Thank you for helping keep Twitter secure!

activities.message: I'd like to blog about this disclosure on 2018-11-30.
activities.markdown_message: I'd like to blog about this disclosure on 2018-11-30.

activities.message:
Hi Edent,

We're currently working on a comprehensive review of application permissions, such as the ones you've identified. Once we better understand the impact of this issue (if any) we will follow up with a bounty decision. Given the upcoming holidays we're not sure that our investigation will be complete by Nov 30th. Would December 14th be ok with you?

Thanks for thinking of Twitter security!
activities.markdown_message:

Would December 14th be ok with you?

Thanks for thinking of Twitter security!

activities.message: Ah, I forgot you had Thanksgiving. Sure. Dec 14th it is. Thanks - and happy holidays :-)
activities.markdown_message: Ah, I forgot you had Thanksgiving. Sure. Dec 14th it is. Thanks - and happy holidays :-)

activities.message: Thanks for understanding our upcoming holidays. We'll be following up with a payout determination shortly and we will update again once we've completed our investigation. Thanks again!
activities.markdown_message: Thanks for understanding our upcoming holidays. We'll be following up with a payout determination shortly and we will update again once we've completed our investigation. Thanks again!

activities.message: Thanks again. As mentioned we’ll keep you updated as we investigate further. As a reminder, please remember to keep the details of this report private until we have fully investigated and addressed the issue.

activities.message:
We consider this issue to be fixed now. Can you please confirm? Separately, if you'd like to write a blog post, can you request disclosure through the drop down menu in HackerOne?

Thank you for helping keep Twitter secure!

activities.message:
When I run the code above - the private iPhone keys - it still says it won't read my DMs. And my DMs are still visible.
It is late here in the UK so I'll check fully in the morning. 
But, no, I don't think it is fixed.

activities.message:
The Google TV API keys appear to be revoked. These other keys are still saying they don't access DMs - but they appear to have access.

There are still problems with:
* Twitter for Android: Consumer key:    3nVuSoBZnx6U4vzUxf5w / Consumer secret: Bcs59EFbbsdF6Sl9Ng71smgStWEGwXXKSjYvPVt7qys
* Twitter for iPhone: Consumer key:    IQKbtAYlXLripLGPWd0HUA / Consumer secret: GgDYlkSvaPxGxC4X8liwpUoqKwwr3lCADbz8A7ADU
* Twitter for iPad: Consumer key:    CjulERsDeqhhjSme66ECg / Consumer secret: IQWdVyqFxghAtURHGeGiWAsmCAGmdW3WmbEx6Hck

I tested those three this morning. They all say "will not be able to access your Direct Messages" - but running the code above prints DMs.
activities.markdown_message:
The Google TV API keys appear to be revoked. These other keys are still saying they don't access DMs - but they appear to have access.

There are still problems with:

  • Twitter for Android: Consumer key: 3nVuSoBZnx6U4vzUxf5w / Consumer secret: Bcs59EFbbsdF6Sl9Ng71smgStWEGwXXKSjYvPVt7qys
  • Twitter for iPhone: Consumer key: IQKbtAYlXLripLGPWd0HUA / Consumer secret: GgDYlkSvaPxGxC4X8liwpUoqKwwr3lCADbz8A7ADU
  • Twitter for iPad: Consumer key: CjulERsDeqhhjSme66ECg / Consumer secret: IQWdVyqFxghAtURHGeGiWAsmCAGmdW3WmbEx6Hck

I tested those three this morning. They all say "will not be able to access your Direct Messages" - but running the code above prints DMs.

activities.message: As per your agreement, I'll be publishing a write up tomorrow - 14th December at around 1200GMT.  Many thanks.
activities.markdown_message: As per your agreement, I'll be publishing a write up tomorrow - 14th December at around 1200GMT. Many thanks.

activities.message:
Hi @edent,

We're specifically concerned whether third party applications could potentially have access to data without user consent. The Twitter for iOS and Twitter for Android applications do not show a user consent dialog because OAuth is an underlying technical detail rather than an approval process to grant permission from an authenticated session. In these flows, the user uses their credentials (username & password) to exchange for a token, which simplifies how these applications are able to consume data. We revoked the Twitter for Google TV application since it is no longer needed and reviewed third party applications to determine if any had the potential to access data that they were not authorized to. We'll approve the disclosure in HackerOne shortly.

Thanks for helping keep Twitter secure!
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @edent,

We're specifically concerned whether third party applications could potentially have access to data without user consent. The Twitter for iOS and Twitter for Android applications do not show a user consent dialog because OAuth is an underlying technical detail rather than an approval process to grant permission from an authenticated session. In these flows, the user uses their credentials (username & password) to exchange for a token, which simplifies how these applications are able to consume data. We revoked the Twitter for Google TV application since it is no longer needed and reviewed third party applications to determine if any had the potential to access data that they were not authorized to. We'll approve the disclosure in HackerOne shortly.

Thanks for helping keep Twitter secure!

summaries.content: The reporter discovered that when a select set of applications are authenticated using a PIN or non-intended OAuth flow, the permission dialog that is shown may not show the permissions that the application has. We do not believe anyone was mislead by the permissions that these applications had or that their data was unintentionally accessed by the Twitter for iPhone or Twitter for Google TV applications as those applications use other authentication flows. To our knowledge, there was not a breach of anyone's information due to this issue. There are no actions people need to take at this time.
summaries.content_html: The reporter discovered that when a select set of applications are authenticated using a PIN or non-intended OAuth flow, the permission dialog that is shown may not show the permissions that the application has. We do not believe anyone was mislead by the permissions that these applications had or that their data was unintentionally accessed by the Twitter for iPhone or Twitter for Google TV applications as those applications use other authentication flows. To our knowledge, there was not a breach of anyone's information due to this issue. There are no actions people need to take at this time.
